Navigation
Name Rascal/Expressions/Values/List
Synopsis List values.
Syntax [ Exp1, Exp2, ... ]

Library functions: import List;
Types
Exp1 Exp2 ... [ Exp1, Exp2, ... ]
T1 T2 ... set[lub(T1, T2, ... )]
Details Append Comprehension Concatenation delete Difference domain Equal getOneFrom head in index Insert insertAt Intersection isEmpty mapper max min NotEqual notin permutations Product reducer reverse size slice sort StrictSubList StrictSuperList SubList Subscription SuperList tail takeOneFrom toMap toMapUnique toSet toString
Description A list is an ordered sequence of values and has the following properties:
  • All elements have the same static type.
  • The order of the elements matters.
  • A list may contain an element more than once.
The type of a list has the form list[T], where T is an arbitrary type.

When variables of type list occur inside a list, their elements are automatically spliced into the surrounding set. This can be prevented by surrounding them with extra [ and ] brackets. Note that this approach is atypical: in Rascal splicing is implicit while in other languages it has to be indicated explicitly by the programmer.

The following functions on lists are provided:

  • Append: Append an element at the end of a list
  • Comprehension: A list comprehension generates a list value.
  • Concatenation: Concatenate two lists.
  • delete: Delete an element from a list.
  • Difference: The difference between two lists.
  • domain: The set of all legal indices of a list.
  • Equal: Equality on lists.
  • getOneFrom: Pick a random element from a list.
  • head: Get the first element(s) from a list.
  • in: Membership test on list elements.
  • index: A list of legal index values of a list.
  • Insert: add an element in front of a list
  • insertAt: Insert an element in a list.
  • Intersection: Intersection of two lists.
  • isEmpty: Test whether a list is empty.
  • mapper: Apply a function to all list elements and return list of results.
  • max: Determine the largest element from a list.
  • min: Determine the smallest element from a list.
  • NotEqual: Not equal operator on lists.
  • notin: Negated membership test on lists.
  • permutations: Compute all permutations of a list.
  • Product: Compute the product of two lists.
  • reducer: Apply a function to successive elements of list and combine the results (deprecated).
  • reverse: Reverse a list.
  • size: Determine the number of elements in a list.
  • slice: Compute a sublist.
  • sort: Sort the elements of a list.
  • StrictSubList: The strict sublist operator on lists.
  • StrictSuperList: The strict super list operator on lists.
  • SubList: The sublist operator on lists.
  • Subscription: Retrieve a list element via its index.
  • SuperList: The super list operator on lists.
  • tail: Take the last element(s) from a list.
  • takeOneFrom: Remove an arbitrary element from a list.
  • toMap: Convert a list of pairs to a map.
  • toMapUnique: Convert a list of tuples to a map.
  • toSet: Convert a list to a set.
  • toString: Convert a list to a string.
Examples 
rascal>[1, 2, 3];
list[int]: [1,2,3]
rascal>[<1,10>, <2,20>, <3,30>];
list[tuple[int,int]]: [
  <1,10>,
  <2,20>,
  <3,30>
]
rascal>[1, "b", 3];
list[value]: [1,"b",3]
rascal>[<"a",10>, <"b",20>, <"c",30>];
list[tuple[str,int]]: [
  <"a",10>,
  <"b",20>,
  <"c",30>
]
rascal>[["a", "b"], ["c", "d", "e"]];
list[list[str]]: [
  ["a","b"],
  ["c","d","e"]
]
List splicing works as follows: 
rascal>L = [1, 2, 3];
list[int]: [1,2,3]
rascal>[10, L, 20];
list[int]: [10,1,2,3,20]
rascal>[10, [L], 20];
list[value]: [
  10,
  [1,2,3],
  20
]

Questions
Question [1]. The type of a list is determined by:




Question [2]. Complete this function that tests that a list of words forms a palindrome. A palindrome is a word that is symmetrical
Fill in 
import List;
public bool isPalindrome(list[str] words){
  return words == ;
}
and make the following true:
isPalindrome(["a", "b", "b", "a"]) == true;
